De Moivre's Theorem

We have seen that in polar form, if \(z=r(\cos\theta +i\sin\theta)\) and \(w=t(\cos\phi +i\sin\phi )\) then the product \(zw\) is: \[\qquad zw=rt(\cos (\theta +\phi ) +i\sin (\theta +\phi ))\]In particular, if \(r=1, t=1\) and \(\theta =\phi\) (i.e. \(z=w=\cos\theta +i\sin\theta\)), we obtain \[\qquad (\cos\theta +i\sin\theta )^2=\cos 2\theta +i\sin 2\theta\] Multiplying each side of the above equation by \(\cos\theta +i\sin\theta\) gives \[\qquad (\cos\theta +i\sin\theta )^3=(\cos 2\theta +i\sin 2\theta)(\cos\theta +i\sin\theta )=\cos 3\theta +i\sin 3\theta\]on adding the arguments of the terms in the product.

Similarly, \[\qquad (\cos\theta +i\sin\theta )^4=\cos 4\theta +i\sin 4\theta.\]After completing \(p\) such products we have: \[\qquad (\cos\theta +i\sin\theta )^p=\cos p\theta +i\sin p\theta\]where \(p\) is a positive integer.

In fact this result can be shown to be true for those cases in which \(p\) is a negative integer and even when \(p\) is a rational number e.g. \(p= \dfrac12\).

Key Point

If \(p\) is a rational number then \[(\cos\theta + i\sin\theta)^p = \cos(p\theta) + i\sin(p\theta).\] This result is known as De Moivre's Theorem.


Recalling from the exponential form that \(\cos\theta +i\sin\theta =e^{i\theta}\), De Moivre’s Theorem is simply a statement of the laws of indices: \[\qquad (e^{i \theta})^p=e^{i p\theta}.\]
